text:
So welcome to the class. Welcome to the last
week of lectures.

So for today, we have
a very exciting topic

that Rex Ying, who's an
assistant professor at Yale. He's an alumni from my research
group here at Stanford.

And through this class, we
learned a lot of methods

that Rex developed. So the GraphSAGE is his
work, the recommender system

stuff we talked
about is Rex's work. Today, he will talk
about explainability

for graph-based machine
learning that is his work. And the graph generation
we talked about,

I think he also had
his fingers in there. So a lot of actually topics that
we talked about in the class

were papers and areas
pioneered by Rex. So what Rex is going to
talk to you about today

is explainability for
graph neural networks, and how do we think about
this kind of explainable

AI, trustworthy machine learning
in the context of graph machine learning. So it'll be kind of a good,
nice overview of that area.
Thank you. Thank you.

OK, hello. Yeah. I think everyone can hear me. So yeah, it feels really
nice to be here again.

I was here until the end of-- but yeah, it feels great to
come back to [INAUDIBLE] again.

And today, I'm going
to share with you guys some exciting
research in the area of trustworthy deep learning,
especially explainability

in the context of GNNs
and graph learning. So let's get started.

So the title of the
talk is XAI for Graphs. And XAI is a very common term
to describe explainable AI,

and today, we're going to
focus on graph and GNNs. So before the lecture, I
usually give a list of readings.

So I suggested something that
are more general explainable

models such as LIME
and SHAP, and I also posted some reference to
GNNExplainer and Explainability

Taxonomy and Trustworthy GNN. So some of these are from the
lab that [INAUDIBLE] leads,

and some others are from
other universities, that give a good overview of what
explainability is, especially

in the context of GNN. So before I dive
into explainability,

I also want to talk a bit about
trustworthy graph learning in general, because
explainability, in my opinion,

is really inseparable from
most other trustworthy context

or trustworthy research
topics in AI and GNN as well. So it covers, broadly
covers a wide range

of topics from explainability,
fairness, robustness, privacy, basically any kind
of issues that

would arise if we
were to let the model to run on like mission critical
scenarios or when people are--

like human decision makers are
involved in working together with the deep learning system.

And there are big challenges
for graph learning. In the context of
graph learning,

a lot of these problems
become especially hard. So the role of graph
topology is, of course,

a key role when we talk
about graph learning, right? We always talk about message
passing, structures, subgraphs,

things like that. Those are important
components that can contribute to model
prediction, model robustness,

and so on, but
existing techniques that are common for
deep learning usually wouldn't capture those.

And also, it becomes
especially hard when those
topological structures are involved if we were to
do quantitative evaluation.

So this lecture will
pretty much cover introduction of some
works that try to solve

these kind of challenges. So the big picture is
basically like this. So I feel like in the area
of trustworthy deep learning,

two very important topics
are what we care about. Adversarial robustness
and explainability.

And mostly other topics
like privacy, fairness, and accountability, all
these are usually borrow

or are built upon existing
techniques in robustness and explainability.

And each of these aspects
play a very critical role in gaining trust from users
of deep learning systems,

from industry users to
academia to researchers, even to domain experts from
like interdisciplinary research

where we apply deep
learning to, say, the field of biology, physics, or
other scientific disciplines.

And as I mentioned, the
challenge in the GNN context

is that the role of graph
topology plays a key role, and we need to quantify how much
the topology is contributing

to explaining a model
or is contributing to robustness of a
model, and we need the quantitative evaluation.

So today, I will first
give a brief introduction of what explainability is,
because not everyone might

be familiar with
the term, and we'll talk about the problem
setting, especially in the context of graphs. And in the second part, I
will discuss GNNExplainer,

which is one of the very widely
used algorithm for explaining GNN predictions right now.

And in the third part, I
will talk about evaluation. So I will talk
about in cases where

ground truth are not available,
which is often the case, right? Like if you want
to explain a model,

you don't always know
what the model is doing, you don't know what should the
ground truth explanation be.

In those cases, how can we
evaluate the performance of explainability? And there are actually
multiple dimensions

where we can say whether
an explainability method is of a higher quality
versus a lower quality.

So that's the three aspects. And we'll start with
explainability and its problem

setting. So we'll talk about
motivations, goals, and settings that we typically care about. And some of it or
most of it actually

applies to many, many other
fields of deep learning as well. And I'll talk about
that, and I don't

talk about the specifics
of it in the context of graph learning. So the key concept
or the key problem

with any kind of trustworthy
deep learning aspects, including explainability,
is that it

has this black-box nature, which
I think by now every one of you should be familiar with.

So black-box nature
basically means that you do not know what
exactly is the model using

as the important parts
of the input that decides the prediction of the model.

And understanding or being
able to open the black box is essential. And explainable AI or
XAI is an umbrella term

for any research
that tries to solve this black-box problem for AI. And why is it useful?

First of all, it enables users
to understand the decision making of the model.

It not only knows that
the model magically outputs this
prediction, but we want to know why it goes from this--

how it arrives at the
answer given the input. It also helps us to gain
trust from human users

of the deep learning system. Imagine that you are
collaborating with a domain expert in, say,
biology, and they

want to know whether their
knowledge in biological science is going to be applicable and
is actually being captured

in the deep learning model. And that's super important. I also listed an archive paper
on a simple-to-read guide.

So this is for general
explainability. So if you're interested
in this area in general, you should definitely
have a look.

But we're talking
about explainability for deep learning.

And we said it's
especially hard because of the black-box nature. But let's try to remember
what was explainable

when we talk about the classical
machine learning methods, and maybe we can borrow
some of the insights

there in order to explain
the deep learning models.

So maybe let's have a quick
recap of what was explainable. So if I were to think about
something that was explainable,

the first reaction that I
had was a linear regression. That's like the most
fundamental method

you can ever think about
in statistics and computer science. So you have some kind of
prediction that is called y,

and then you have
some input features: x1, x2, x3, and all that. And then you have some
weights, linear weights

associated with each of
these input features. So we call them
W1, W2, and so on. And this was
extremely explainable

just because you can
have a plot here. So you fit this data into
a line, a linear model.

And because it is
linear, you can naturally define this slope. So this green arrow here.

So it basically corresponds
to each of these weights. Imagine that your x-axis
is one of these axis,

like let's say x1, and
your y-axis is actually your prediction y, so
your slope directly

indicates how important the
feature x1 is to the output.

If the slope is very steep, that
means the feature is actually critical for the model.

It has a large coefficient. If the slope is very
flat, this feature

is basically not going to
influence your prediction at all. So we can have some kind
of explanation like this.

A change in delta x amount
to, let's say, feature x1 is going to result in an
increase in prediction

by y amount and delta y amount. So that kind of
sentence can tell us

how important a feature is. But this is not so easy
in deep learning model, as you would imagine.

There isn't even a slope here. The second thing--
intuition I would have

was dimension reduction. That's, again, like one of
the most fundamental models. We have some data in the
very high dimensional space.

We project them down into
low dimensional manifolds, and then we can do
like clustering,

we can-- importantly, we can
care about decision boundaries. Let's say we have the red
classes and the green classes,

and we can draw those
decision boundaries. Some of those give
linear boundaries, some models give
access line boundaries,

some models give
non-trivial boundaries. And in deep learning,
these kind of boundaries can be very complicated,
but it's something

that we want to understand
in order to explain a deep learning model.

The last thing I want
to talk about in terms of what was explainable
is kind of decision tree.

Again, it's like something
you would imagine. It's extremely like
self explainable.

Like I will say
you don't even have to have some additional
things to think about.

Like let's say you
have a decision tree, you know exactly what
each feature plays

a role in the decision tree. And we can say something that
is at the aggregate level.

For example, if the condition
of some kind of node is met, let's say the node is the petal
length of this classical data

set, the petal length is less
than 4.75, it is likely-- 80% of the time, it is likely
to be classified as true.

So it's just like a direct
consequence of a decision tree. OK, so now, having revisited
some of the traditionally very

explainable models,
the question now is, how can we
bring some of these or retain some of
these explainability

when we transfer to a
deep version of the model? And indeed, there
are many ways to do

that in the general
field of explainable AI. And typically,
corresponding to the slope,

the linear regression
slope that I talked about, there are techniques
such as the saliency that

talk about the importance
of, say, words features, nodes in the graph.

It tries to extract these
important structure. And importantly for
graphs, we might even have to extract the important
scores for subgraphs.

So this is definitely
one approach that is inspired from
linear regression.

Another kind of approach
is called attribution, which means that
this kind of feature

contributes to x percent
of our prediction. This is also definitely a
result of dimension reduction

and linear regression
inspired from this kind of explainable models. And then finally, there is
also concepts and prototypes.

So it talks about, in
general, this class has certain kind
of characteristics. You can see them as
like a particular group

under like a branch
of a decision tree. So those are methods
that are also

trying to bring some of
those traditionally very explainable models to the
deep learning context.

All right, so another aspect
is that explainable AI can

be different from
different domains, but underlying all
these applications, we have a very
similar principle.

So for example, in
computer vision, what was explainable, right? So let's say we
have an image here,

and we want to talk about why
is it being classified as, say, like a cat with
some probability or a dog

with some probability. And we can look at it with
respect to the dog logit.

So treat the vector on the
right as the prediction logit after the softmax.

So if we look at
the cat, then it highlights the portion
of the cat at the bottom. So this was kind of
saliency map that highlights

importance of each pixel. So it has a cat. And then if we switch
it to the dog logit,

then it's going to tell us what
was the part of the image that

helps the model decide that
it's kind of like a dog image, and then the dog
part was highlighted. So this is an example
in computer vision,

but we see the pattern, right? So we want to
extract like a subset of the input that
are particularly

important for the prediction. That's what we did in
linear regression, that's also what we're doing in
CV, and as we will see,

it's also the case for
NLP and graphs as well. Let's say in the context of
natural language processing,

we have some input, and
we're doing this sentiment classification. We're predicting
whether the sentence

has a positive or
negative sentiment. We run through some kind of
language model, whatever,

and the explanation
is going to highlight the portion of
the sentences that contribute to the sentiment.

For example, the
entertaining or cool effects, those have high
importance values

to the prediction of being
like positive sentiment. On the other hand, if you
look at the bottom row,
there's the negative part. There is a bad and peeling off.

So these words that have
negative connotations will get highlighted. So again, it's a
subset of the input

that particularly contributes
to the prediction made by the model.

Again, same for graph learning. This is what we're going
to talk about today. Again, the same principle.

We're going to extract
a subset of the input such that it contributes to
a particular prediction made

by the model. But in this case,
it's more complicated because we not only have a
subset of feature dimensions,

which we usually
care about, let's say in similar to a subset of
pixels and stuff like that,

but there's also this
structural component. We want to extract
the subset of graphs,

the topological structure,
like a subgraph, such that it particularly contributes
to the model prediction.

So keep in mind we have
both aspects to capture when we go through the methods.

So why is this important? Why do we need to
capture structure? Why do we need to
capture feature at the same time for
GNN explainability?

So typically, we have
two kinds of purposes

in order to explain
both aspects. So we might sometimes
want the GNNs to,

or we want to explain the
ground truth phenomenon. Let's say I have a molecule
property prediction task,

right? Given a molecule, I predict
whether it is toxic or not. Something like that. So we want to understand what
makes the molecule toxic.

We don't just want a model
that magically outputs me toxic versus
non toxic, but we

want to find the reasons
why it is toxic or not. So that's-- like trying to
investigate the ground truth

phenomenon is particularly
important in like any kind of science applications.

But on the bottom side,
it's about explaining model prediction. Let's say this is
another scenario where

we have a customer that is
applying for a loan in a bank, and we have a bank transaction
network, we run a graph neural

net on top of it, we
predict whether it is advisable to approve
the loan for the customer.

So it's, again, a binary
classification, yes or no, and in this case, it says no.

So what we want to
understand in this case is why does the model recommend
no loan for this person?

Is it because it has
a low credit history, is it because it has-- the
loan amount is too big, some kind of reason?

We don't just want
to deny a customer because the model predicts no. We want to give them
reasons that can help

them be successful next time. So instead of explaining
the ground truth, we're more like
explaining the model.

You can think of it as almost
like debugging the model to see why does
the model recommend

no loan for this person? Is it because of this feature,
is it because of that feature, is this a fair thing to do?

Let's say if the model-- we discover through
explainability that the model is
recommending no loan because

of some protected
characteristics, such as gender, race,
this kind of thing,

that's definitely like a no. We shouldn't be doing
that, and that's what explainability can help.

And in this case,
gender, stuff like that can be like a feature, whereas
transaction behavior can

be like a subgraph. So that's exactly what
we talk about when we said a subgraph
and a feature both

are important for explaining
such a prediction.

And I also listed some
references in case people are interested. So there have been a
lot of works in terms

of explainable AI in general. So there are like
proxy-based approach. SHAP is a very popular one
used in industry and academia

as well. There are saliency or
gradient-based methods such as Grad-CAM, there
is attention mechanism.

We talked about graph
attention models here. And we get those
attention values, and they can be
quite useful when

explaining model prediction. We can look at which one is the
current node paying attention to, and is that node--

that kind of pattern
important for the prediction? So attention is definitely like
another important approach.

And the final part
of section one is just going to be
reasons why explainability

is an important topic. First of all, it gives
us a sense of trust.

We understand what the
Black box is doing, we no longer treat
it as magic, we are able to understand
what are the features that

cause this model to make
certain predictions. That's very important for
fairness and debugging

and many other reasons. And sometimes it also gives
us a sense of causality.

It's not always the
case, but a lot of times, it gives us some
kind of causality. So like certain feature
or certain kind of input

causes a prediction
to be like that. So we can-- depending on
whether the outcome is something

we desire, we might
want to fix it, or we might want to just utilize
that kind of inductive bias

to understand the
phenomenon better. It also has a big implication
in terms of transferability.

Let's give you a
very simple example. So if I'm-- let's say in my
data set, I have a lot of dogs.

I want to classify whether
the image has a dog or not. I have a lot of dogs, but
every time a dog appears,

there's also a
person that appears. So that's just a
particular characteristic of this data set.

And we can use
explainability to see whether the reason
we're predicting a dog

is because there's a dog
or there is a person. And it's just like there is a
high correlation between person

and dog in this
particular data set. So understanding which one
is going to be the case

is going to have a big
implication in terms of transferability, because if
you have a new data set that

has dogs but don't
have any person in it, then of course your model
wouldn't be able to transfer.

And finally, I talked about
fairness and ethical decision making. We want to think about
whether the explainability

or explanation made by
the model is something that's reasonable to do. And if it's not, we should
do something that fixes it.

But explainability
let us at least investigate this phenomenon.

So I will also talk
about the settings here. There are many ways
we can formulate

this problem of explainability. And here is different ways that
we can formulate the setting.

So first of all, we
can explain by target. So we can say, it
is an explanation for a particular instance
versus an explanation

for the entire model, or for a
particular class of the model. Instance-level means that I
focus on one particular data

point. Let's say this image or
this node in a graph, and say, why is this
node being predicted as no loan for this customer?

And so we're only going to
explain for that instance, right? The explanation is
specific to that instance. Whereas model-level
explanation would mean

what is the general
characteristic of a toxic molecule? So it might give us some
understanding of the functional

group of the molecule, some
interaction between atoms, what, in general, a toxic
molecule looks like.

So those are more like
model-level or class-level explanation. And in particular,
we're going to focus on

in this instance level because
I guess it's the first step. Model-level explanations
are out there.

There are some papers
on it, but it's still a very active area of research.

And in fact, I'm doing
like an ongoing work for model-level explanation
on GNNS as well.

And settings can also be
classified in other ways. We can also say explainability
settings by stages.

We can have explainability being
injected into this pipeline at different stages.

We can inject it before
the model fitting. So we can think of it as like
being inherent in the model.

Let's say I have a model
that is intrinsically explainable or
interpretable, which means that you can use attention
or something like that,

and once the model is
optimized, we automatically have that explanation. So that's often called
ante-hoc and sometimes called

intrinsic interpretability. And there's another
type of explainability which we are going
to focus on that

is post-hoc explainability. So this means that I have a
model that is already trained. Let's say it's a pre-trained
model or like any kind

of network where we
already fixed the weights, it's already well optimized. And we want to have an
additional module that's

built on top of
it, we just bring in this additional
explainability module

to investigate why the model
makes certain prediction. So that's often called
post-hoc explainability.

The disadvantage is, of course,
you have an additional module component, it's not like
intrinsic to the model,

so it requires post-processing
and even like optimization, as we will see, to
generate the explanation.

That's more time
consuming and so on, but the advantage is that it's
kind of agnostic to the model.

We don't require the model
itself to be interpretable. We don't require it
to have attention.

We don't require
it to have, say, some kind of linear components
or anything like that.

Any kind of black-box
model, we should be able to apply
post-hoc explainability. So that's kind of the difference
in terms of their stages.

And another-- Yes. A short question. So I'm assuming there's
also learned weights

for the explainability model
that happens post-hoc, right? Yeah. So what is stopping us from then
going deep learning on that too

and then having a
model that explains the explanation
of the model that explains the explainer,
the explainer of the model? Yeah, yeah, yeah, there are
people who actually do that.

Like in CV for
example, last year, I remember there
was a paper, you use a deep learning model
to generate an explanation.

In fact, a deep generative
model to generate the explanation that
explains another deep image

classification model. So there are definitely
people who do that. And a lot of times,
those actually give us a lot
better performance.

The only thing that can
be a little bit worrying is it kind of applies
like all the problems

of like learned classifier. So like we might be worried
that the model is not robust,

it's not predicting us
the correct explanation, is not stable. if I perturb the
pixels a little bit,

it predicts completely different
things, different things as explanation. So like all these issues.

But it's definitely like
a possible approach. People always try to do that. And you mentioned
this recursion, right?

Like explaining something
that is-- trying to explain something else. I haven't seen
people doing that. But yeah, I don't know if
there is any use case of such,

but I think people
are on the first level currently, like trying
to just generate

a good explanation for
a deep learning model, not really investigating what
the explainer itself is doing.

a large language model nowadays,
then we can come up with ways additionally to investigate
what the explainer is doing.

But that's definitely like
a natural line of thought. So yeah, anyways good question.

So the third kind of
setting difference is that applicability can
also specify the setting.

We can be model-specific. That means that the
explainability method is only going to be applied to a
certain class of models.

But we can also try to
be model agnostic, which means that no matter what the
underlying model is doing,

we are always able to
explain something out of it. Or at least model
agnostic to some extent,

let's say any kind of GNNs
or any kind of transformers,

things like that. So I think I've finished
everything about explainability

and problem setting. Let me know if there is
any question by the way. Feel free to raise your hand
if there's any question.

But I will give you
guys an example of what we have done on a GNN explainer,
which is the first and very

commonly used GNN explainability
methods that is still quite popular nowadays.

And I'll go on to how
we evaluate this thing. So I think we talked about
this example already.

We have some kind of
transaction networks in the financial markets. And it can be formulated as
a graph, where we have nodes

connected through transactions. And we can use a
graph neural network to predict whether each user
is trustworthy or risky client,

and then we can
decide whether we want to give a loan
to the person or not. And there are a lot
more applications.

I'm sure you guys are
already exposed to them after taking this class. For example, in the
recommender system,

people get recommended
with different items. You can see it as a kind
of a predicting what

the person might buy in future. It can also be a
molecule classification. I think in the
past few lectures,

you might have talked about
molecule generation or molecule property prediction, predicting
the property of the molecule

as a whole graph. And I have the fraudulent, the
financial network example here.

So in those cases,
we are explaining different kinds of targets. So in the first one, we're
explaining link prediction.

We're explaining what is
connecting each other, what will be the future connection.

In the second case, we're
explaining graph classification because we are having one
label for an entire molecule

as a graph. And in the third
case, it's going to be a node classification.

Every node represents
a user, and we want to see-- investigate
why the user is, say, classified as fraudulent
or not trustworthy, risky,
and all that. so yeah, different targets. So let's consider all of these.

So as I said, this
pipeline is going to be a post-hoc
framework, which

means that this is going to be
an extra module that we bring

in and try to explain the GNN
that we have already trained.

it's the post-hoc setting. So how it works is going to
be like at training time, we optimize the GNN on the
training graph as usual, right?

We train, let's say, a
GNN for the molecule, and then we save
the training model. So that model is kind
of fixed already.

And at test time,
we are explaining the prediction made by the GNN. So let's say GNN make prediction
that the molecule is toxic,

now say if we're on
an unseen instance, we have never seen this
instance before, have never

seen this molecule
before, and we want to understand what
makes this molecule toxic. And that is where we bring
the explainability module.

As the student just said,
it can be a deep module, it can be a very shallow module.

And in fact, GNNExplainer is
sort of like a shallow module, I would say. So it's not something
like a deep model that

is optimizing for explanation,
but like a lot of deep model

based explanations are
available nowadays as well.

So these are the overall goals. We want to explain different
kinds of tasks, right?

No classification, graph
classification, or whatever. We also want the
explanation to be post-hoc,

which means it is
model agnostic. We want to be able to apply it
to any kind of message passing networks.

And we also want
the predictions to-- like we also want
to take into account

that some of the
predictions are based on a complex combination of
nodes, edges between them,

motifs/subgraphs. Like not just the feature
information but also the complex
structural information

and how that contributes
to the model prediction. And one thing to note is
that different from, say,

computer vision,
gradient is typically less reliable on real-world
graphs because a lot of times,

there is this discrete
nature of having an edge versus not having an edge. It's kind of 0, 1 scenario,
and gradients are often

behaving less well compared
to continuous things, where,

for example, like pixel, you
can have values between say 0 to 255 or something, like
that's more continuous.

So in those cases,
saliency or gradient, which was a common method in
CV, typically works less well.

So we're looking at model
agnostic explanation, right? So the target is basically
to be able to explain

any kind of message passing
network, so anything that uses this kind of
message passing structure.

And we want to discover
what is important. So by the way, this
has the potential

to apply to transformer and
anything like that as well. So any time you have those kind
of message passing structure.

And there are two
kinds of explanations we want to extract. One is the structural
explanation, and one is the
feature explanation.

So feature explanation should
be very easy to understand. I crossed out some of
the feature dimensions. So this basically means
that some of the features

are less important, some of
features are more important. So we want to understand what
has contributed to the model

prediction. Is it this node feature or
that node feature, right?

Something like that. And at the same
time, we also want to extract the structural
explanation, which

is about the topology
of the graph. So let's say the green
part of this graph

are the edges that
contribute to a prediction, from the green part
of the topology,

we can perhaps
understand what has-- what has been going on and why
is this structure corresponding

to toxic molecule, let's say. So maybe in the transaction
network example, this structural
explanation can be

something like fraudulent
transaction patterns. Let's say in the
molecule, it can

be some kind of
substructure of the molecule that forms an important

minus is on the green part.

to make the model predict the
